Description: Scaraboid in the shape of a Black African Head, in Egyptian blue; underside with hieroglyphic signs arranged vertically with squatting deity (possibly goddess Maat) and Maat feather above neb-basket sign; motif possibly incised.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Chautauqua Institution, New York. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This piece is now lost. Brief description ('negro head blue paste') with sketch from Chautauqua distribution list of the Egypt Exploration Fund. It is possible to identify the scaraboid with Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII no. 32 and Petrie 1889, pl. 61, no. 1959. The drawing of the motif on the underside, much clearer in the publication (goddess Maat and her feather above a nb basket), matches the sketch and the publication states that it is made out of blue paste. However, the publication illustrated this piece as if it was a scarab and not an African head-shaped scaraboid. For examples of Egyptian blue scaraboids in the shape of Black African head, see: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.726 and 88.872; BM 1886,0401.1691 and BM 1886,0401.1683. This piece belongs to a type which was produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on this production, see Webb forthcoming) and was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Carthage, Kerkouan, Sicily and Gibraltar, but also in Greece, Cyprus and Rhodes (Gorton 1996, 118-121, type XXXIII, subtype A5-24 for scarabs not scaraboids, see especially A21 for this piece). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1889, Historical scarabs: a series of drawings from the principal collections arranged chronologically, London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1889 / Historical scarabs: a series of drawings from the principal collections arranged chronologically (pl. 61, no. 1959) (possibly)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 119, Type XXXIII A21) (possibly, but A23 on drawing)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.04) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Chautauqua Institution, Chautauqua (NY)
